title: Presentations
text: Open Full Screen

title: About
text: About this site

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Motivation

Show real work: authentic portfolio of papers, posters, code, datasets, and notebooks.
Reproducible examples: Quarto notebooks with math/citations.
Real tooling & credibility: Git/GitHub workflow; issues/PRs show collaboration and history.
Own it + publish fast: portable repo, custom domain, free hosting via GitHub Pages.

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Agenda

Getting started with GitHub
Ready to roll with RStudio
Quick guide to Quarto
Customizing your content

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Create a New Repository

Log in
Click the green “New” button
Name it

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Some Details

Give it a professional-sounding name
Add a description
Choose “Public” visibility
Add a README file

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Why Public?
If you want GitHub Pages to host your website for free, then the repository must be public. If you make your repository private, then you have to pay for GitHub to host your website.

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Create
Click “Create”

Once created, copy the link to your repository from the URL

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Open the Repository

Open RStudio
File -> New Project -> Version Control -> Git
Paste the URL (everything else should auto-fill)
Choose a subdirectory
Click “Create Project”

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Check it
Project name should match the repository

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Open a Terminal
Tools -> Terminal -> New Terminal

title: Brian Harrold
text:
In the Terminal
quarto create-project mysite --type website

title: Brian Harrold
text:
New Folder
Open the new folder mysite/ in the Files pane.

_quarto.yml
index.qmd
about.qmd
styles.css

title: Brian Harrold
text:
In _quarto.yml
project:
  type: website
  output-dir: ../docs

title: Brian Harrold
text:
In the Terminal
quarto render mysite/

You should see a new docs/ folder in the Files Pane.

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Pushing to GitHub
Under Git Options

Commit… (Ctrl+Alt+M)
Check to “Stage” all updates
Add a commit message
Press Commit
Press Push

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Deploying Pages
In GitHub:

Settings
Pages
Source = Deploy from branch
Choose main and /docs from the drop downs

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Showing the link

Go to repository’s homepage
Locate the About section
Click the gear (Settings)
Check the box “Use Your GitHub Pages Website”
Click Save Settings

title: Brian Harrold
text:
_quarto.yml Project
project:
  type: website
  output-dir: ../docs
  render: 
    - "*.qmd"               # render real site pages
  resources: 
    - assets/**             # copy static assets
    - "!assets/**/*.qmd"    # but never copy .qmd slide sources

execute: 
  freeze: auto              # for faster builds

title: Brian Harrold
text:
_quarto.yml Website
website:
  title: "Brian Harrold"
  site-url: https://stat-brain.github.io/bharrold/
  search: true                   # allows users to search your site
  navbar:
    collapse-below: lg
    right:
      - href: index.qmd
        text: Home
      - href: research.qmd       # add new files for each new page
        text: Research
      - href: about.qmd
        text: About
      - icon: github             # can add social media icons
        href: https://github.com/stat-brain
        aria-label: GitHub

title: Brian Harrold
text:
_quarto.yml Format
format:
  html:
    theme:
      - cosmo              # base Bootswatch
      - brand              # your SCSS theme (optional)
    css: styles.css        # extra tweaks (optional)
    toc: true              # page sidebar
    toc-location: right
    anchor-sections: true  # adds linkable headings

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Examples

My Professional Website
Built into an R package
A Great Example (Not Mine)


Note: you can get a domain name and use that with your GitHub website

title: Brian Harrold
text:
Hi, I’m Brian
I’m a graduate student in statistics at the University of South Carolina. This site shares my research, teaching materials, and R/Quarto tools.




I build reproducible R/Quarto workflows for education data—bridging research, teaching, and open-source tools.


Research Teaching Presentations About
